channel.title: CS vs SE , help needed?
channel.description:
Like what is the difference between both? I read that SE is obviously specialized in writing software , programs , and such. But i don't really understand what a CS major exactly do? I researched a bit , but no one has a straight answer , all i could conclude is that you do a bit of everything? I don't get it.
And also which do you think is better to choose? or can i go with both? I really have no idea what to expect out of either.
Help from your experience would be nice. Thanks.

item.title: CS vs SE , help needed?
item.dc:creator: @T41 t4
item.description:
@T41 wrote:

A person with a CS degree can do everything someone with an SE degree can except a CS degree is more for freethinkers whereas SE is for people who want to be cogs in the corporate wheel. That’s my takeaway through experience.

Read full topic

item.title: CS vs SE , help needed?
item.dc:creator: @xx_matty_xx Justin Bieber
item.description:
@xx_matty_xx wrote:

[quote=“naseem142, post:4, topic:553689”]I see… So i can start off with cs to get a general knowledge over the things that se won’t cover and then work on a masters for se, i think that would be fine. I don’t mind studying both.[/quote]A lot of CS masters courses are full of shit so yeah that sounds like the better choice.

item.title: CS vs SE , help needed?
item.dc:creator: @justaguy justaguy
item.description:
@justaguy wrote:

What the Biebs said pretty much summarizes the differences. This differs by institution, but in my experience you learn more mathematics than someone in SE does due to the nature of studying algorithms and data structures rigorously. When it comes to finding jobs, they are considered pretty much the same job. The only difference becomes apparent if you have a master’s or PhD where you might be working more specifically on CS vs. SE topics for research. In my own experience, all my professional jobs have been as a software engineer, even though I’m in CS. Same job.

Read full topic

item.title: CS vs SE , help needed?
item.dc:creator: @xx_matty_xx Justin Bieber
item.description:
@xx_matty_xx wrote:

It varies a lot between institutions but in general there’s a lot of overlap between the two. Computer science focuses more on algorithms, data structures, and some lower level stuff like C and computer architecture. Software engineering also involves programming, but is more focused on things like development methodologies, architecture and design. So an advantage to taking SE is that you’ll be more prepared for the workplace in general, but will be lacking knowledge about more technical stuff. If you took CS you’d have a better understanding of how computers work and be able to write more specialised software, but might not be aware of the importance of TDD and mess up a big project.

Read full topic
